page.name: Topic 4.2: Outreach and recruitment
page.content:
Overview

Developing an effective communications strategy is crucial to being able to promote your pre-apprenticeship program. This will help ensure you reach your target participants as well as attract potential partners or funders.

Effective communications and outreach use a variety of channels depending on their target participants ’ needs and interests:

  • Alumni networks. Alumni are great for promoting your pre-apprenticeship through word of mouth, features in marketing materials, and mentoring. Think about ways you can tell positive stories about the real-life benefits of your pre-apprenticeship.
  • In-person events. In-person events are a great way to meet potential participants. Make sure you record the details of any interested participants so you can follow up with them.
  • Social media. To boost your social media reach, identify individuals and organizations with deep roots in the community and build a relationship with them.
  • Traditional media. To complement other channels, effective pre-apprenticeships also use more traditional outlets — such as printed flyers, events, and local press. It’s important to leave promotional materials where your participants are likely to see them. This could be anywhere from a hairdresser to a library.

Effective outreach must be tailored to specific audiences. In developing your outreach and recruitment strategy, consider the following key questions:

  • Who is your audience? Try to get specific. Think about details such as their age, gender, occupation, and interests.
  • Where and how might you engage these different audiences? For example, through a social media platform, newsletter, or events.
  • How will you measure your progress toward engaging these audiences? For example, the percentage of people who open your newsletter or whether your social media following has grown.

Recommended reading 

  • Creating compelling learning value propositions (University of Colorado). A value proposition paints a clear picture of what your program has to offer participants. This blog post will help you think about how to craft your own value proposition in the activity below.
  • Developing a plan for communication (Center for Community Health and Development). This guide outlines the steps for creating a communications strategy, including identifying your audience, crafting your message, and choosing the right channels.
  • Are we there yet? A communications evaluation guide (Lumina Foundation). It’s important to evaluate your communications to check that you’re reaching the right people and that your messaging is working. This step-by-step guide outlines how to set clear objectives and measure your progress.
  • The what, why, and how of social media for higher education (Digital Marketing Institute). This article provides an overview of how social media can be used to promote your program and increase student engagement.
